title: Adrenal Incidentaloma with Subclinical Cushing Syndrome
setup_script: “A 50-year-old woman undergoes abdominal CT for renal colic, which incidentally reveals a 4 cm right adrenal mass. She has a history of mild hypertension and obesity. Laboratory workup shows elevated late-night salivary cortisol and failure to suppress on a 1 mg overnight dexamethasone test, consistent with subclinical Cushing syndrome. How would you proceed with this patient?”

dynamic_flow.reply: “What diagnoses would you consider for an adrenal incidentaloma?”
“The results show elevated late-night salivary cortisol, nonsuppression on dexamethasone test, normal plasma metanephrines, and normal aldosterone/renin ratio. DHEAS is mildly elevated.”
“CT scan shows a 4 cm right adrenal mass with 15 Hounsfield units and borderline washout characteristics.”
“What features of this mass would make you consider adrenalectomy versus observation?”
“The patient asks about risks and benefits of laparoscopic adrenalectomy compared with observation. How do you counsel her?”
“The patient’s blood pressure is moderately elevated. What preoperative considerations do you have?”
“You perform a laparoscopic right adrenalectomy. Please describe the critical intraoperative steps.”
“The mass is resected without spillage and specimen is removed intact. What are your postoperative concerns?”
“Given the patient’s suppressed contralateral adrenal, how would you manage steroid coverage perioperatively?”
“Final pathology demonstrates adrenocortical adenoma with no features concerning for carcinoma.”
“On post-op day 2, the patient has fatigue and nausea. Morning cortisol is low. How do you manage this?”
“What are your recommendations for surveillance and long-term management?”

critical_decision_points: Appropriate hormonal evaluation of adrenal incidentaloma.
Use of imaging features and size to guide operative decision-making.
Safe and technically sound laparoscopic adrenalectomy.
Long-term surveillance for recurrence and management of metabolic effects.
